Hi
I rebased and Travis Build# 4754 is now in the pipeline.

Both subdirectories and siblings have issues but subdirectory seems to be the lesser of two evils as the fallback. There is also PipelineOptions.tempLocation but that may not work at all since the IOChannelFactory may not be equivalent or there will be other underlying storage differences like the GCS bucket may be part of a different GCP project.

In the referenced example of the person reading the pipeline in later, paths that are *\* will still encompass the temp files. Sibling fails when the output location is a GCS bucket since you can't just create arbitrary siblings at that level or in a local file system the path is "/".

Does it make sense for the IOChannelFactory to own creating temp file locations?

@dhalperi:
- If we write to a temp directory inside the path, a user's glob like "*_/_" will match the temp files - that's why I opted for a sibling, it seems cleaner in terms of isolation.
- I used Path.resolve on Path objects provided by the IOChannelFactory (Path is an interface), so it should be ok. And I, indeed, had to add sibling resolution methods to our IOChannelFactory's to make it work.

@lukecwik:
- Agreed that we can't use tempLocation for the reasons you listed.
- Agreed that this solution won't work when the user wants to write to a root path (raw GCS bucket or /something on a filesystem). Perhaps in this case we should _require_ them to provide a temp location, since there's no obvious safe choice the SDK can make for them?
- By "creating temp file locations", you mean "I want to write to _this_ path, give me a scratchpad for that" - i.e. move the generation of a temp location from FileBasedSink to IOChannelFactory?

Hey @robertwb, test failures seem unrelated to my CL (but perhaps I misunderstood)? Can you take a look and verify?
Can you please rebase with last changes ? Else I can do it for you. Thanks.

The IT test failure looks like the known inconsistency issue mentioned in [BEAM-747](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-747), and the unit test failure was due to a `BindException` on the embedded Kafka port.
Let's keep going, I'm sure I'll have more commits before this is LGTMed so the tests will run again.

One thing I don't understand is ROS tests - they're clearly not running or they would fail on `testSessionsCombineWithContext` specifically (known issue) - @kennknowles any chance you know why ?
This is a serious issue, last time those tests were off we missed-out on a lot of progress and it took me a while to catch-up. I really want to remove all of the runner's unit tests (batch, and in the future streaming) but I have to know that the ROS tests run on PreCommit.

Yes, the test failures are due to not having https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/1110 (which, incidentally, is why I didn't have time to get to this yesterday). 

Generally, it's preferred if the commit messages themselves have the descriptive message (a one-liner title, plus any amount of stuff in the body), with truly separate changes being in separate commits (if not PRs, though that's not required). 

I'll rebase this and make sure all tests pass manually (they did before, so I'm relatively confident they will).
Thanks Robert, will try to following the separate (descriptive) commits per logical change in future contributions.

Figured out how to update the commit messages.
The first commit message now has the same details as my first comment in this CL (ie description of the full changes).

Thanks. 

I edited the commit message a bit more (as "Several enhancements to Dataflow" applies to essentially every commit in this repo, and "part 2 of 2" doesn't make much sense without part 1 (and for future reference, the grouping of commits in a PR often makes numbering the parts unneeded).
LGTM. Thank you.

The tests have silly failures that should have been fixed by my last commit. I'll squash them all together before merging.
Some of my questions:
- Should we add another directory within `transforms/` or should I just add one file?
- For more complex cases (items that have `url`, `label`, etc), I went with a dictionary because `DisplayDataItem` receives other inputs such as `namespace` on construction. It felt more natural if these didn't have to be specified by the user - but I can change it to something else if necessary.
- Let me know if you think more tests are necessary.
is there a way to replace Eclipse's compiler with one that properly implements the Java spec?

It seems as though other packages go with [/\] instead of [\\/] such as checkstyle (https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/master/config/suppressions.xml)
It would be good to use the typical format for this and its strange that we used \\/
R: @lukecwik

Who says it doesn't properly implement the Java spec?  In particular, according to the spec:
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se7/html/jls-13.html
A compiler is allowed to:
"Reordering the fields, methods, or constructors in an existing type declaration."

But the answer is no.  Within eclipse, you don't have any option other than to use the Eclipse compiler.

BTW:  the IBM compiler on AIX would also have a similar issue.   This is something I have (too much) experience with in CXF.   In CXF, we have a JavaToWSDL command.  In our test suites, we had to be careful of direct compares as Eclipse, IBM, and Oracle/Sun compilers would output methods in different orders and result in the operations in the WSDL being different.   This is also why in JAXB, the XmlType annotation has a propOrder attribute to specify the order as it cannot be derived consistently from the output of the compiler.
@lukecwik thanks, see update

We test with more than just Oracle JDK already, which is why I am generally suspicious of Eclipse's compiler. In this case, it seemed like Eclipse's compiler actually has and/or had a bug: https://github.com/google/auto/issues/292

Actually, that's slightly different, but that issue DOES provide good information for a better alternative.  The "fix" does prevent the sorting of the attributes/methods for the current class.  However, it still results in sorted stuff inherited from interfaces.   Thus, a better fix is to define the "public abstract MetricName name()" methods on the class so AutoValue see's those in the order it needs them.
This also needs a test jar dep. Hold for update.
(I should add here, that I do not at all disagree with making things explicit rather than implicit :)
LGTM , merging

R: @lukecwik @davorbonaci
LGTM barring travis problems. There are reasonable followups which can be done while we clean up the TriggerStateMachine implementation.
As for ROS tests, they run only in post-commit, both just for latency of results and because, taken all together, they would time out Jenkins and Travis.

With some Jenkins hackery to parallelize sub-builds, it seems feasible to:
1. Run unit tests
2. (sub tasks) Run ROS tests for each runner in parallel, skipping unit tests

I've set up Jenkins to do such things, so I know it can be done in general, but I'm not particularly close with the Apache Jenkins setup.
Sorry missed this

This memory saving is only important in the case of initial splitting and depends on how initial splitting works in BigQuery.
(Also LGTM)
And merged.

I think that this is generally on the wrong path. Runners should not need to override temporal constants in specific transforms to get sane behavior. I believe the simple rule of thumb should be "readers should return as soon as they are able" + "runners may poll advance() in a loop for a certain period of time if it returned too fast" + "runners must tolerate sources that take a long time to start or advance, because real systems operate that way".

I think we're violating all of these in various places, but that combined these principles add up to a good solution. Thoughts?

(Also, if we reach agreement we should probably summarize to dev@ list?)
`ReshuffleTriggerTest` still provides unit tests for `ReshuffleTrigger`. Both are going away ASAP, but this restore should definitely be done.

I'd be happy to summarize this once we have something, and I agree with what you write Dan, but it seems that this was an issue for the `DirectRunner` as explained in this [conversation](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/1071).
According to your suggestion, we should set the two "wait" properties to something like 10 msec, correct ?
If the `DirectRunner` can handle it, I'd be happy to change the ticket, PR, and commit.

I really don't think it makes sense to reuse `JAVA_CLASS`. We could move towards one common `CLASS` type, but I think we want some way of distinguishing Java vs Python. For example, imagine a UI which recognizes Beam SDK classes by the module prefix and links to the relevant Java/Python documentation.

My preference is to add `PYTHON_CLASS` type and update runners. @bjchambers may also have thoughts.
